Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High-Performance Computing Cluster for Research and Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal #: 12-28291
PI(s): Majumdar, Kingshuk
Kremar, Maja; Szarecka, Agnieszka
Institution: Grand Valley State University
Title: MRI/Acq.: High-Performance Computing Cluster for Research and Education
Project Proposed:
This project, acquiring a computing cluster with multiple nodes, aims to have the equipment serve as a central resource for high performance computing at the institution. Complementing a small 8-node computing cluster, this cluster supports research and training of faculty and students in physics and cellular and molecular biology and provides the opportunity to foster an emerging community of interdisciplinary researchers from other fields interested in solving complex computational problems. Some research activities include:
- Order-disorder phases of two and three dimensional magnetic spin systems;
- First principle calculations using density functional theory; and
- Quantum mechanical modeling of the binding pocket and antibiotic resistance in a set of beta-lactamases.
The instrumentation provides a means to test, optimize, and carry out some computations locally.
Broader Impacts:
Serving as a powerful stimulus for the recruitment of undergraduates that include first generation, minority and non-traditional students, the instrumentation should also leverage individual research funding in a mainly undergraduate-serving institution and foster further the integration of research and education. Moreover, this acquisition should promote an exciting learning environment for the next generation of students providing an accessible entry to research and education at the frontiers of Computational Science, Information Technology, and Cluster Computing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The High-Performance Computing Cluster (HPC) funded by NSF-MRI grant allowed GVSU researchers in Physics and Cell and Molecular Biology to do cutting edge research in the sciences that they were unable to do before, allowing them to make substantial improvements in their research methodologies and to broaden areas of inquiry.  The diverse range of topics investigated by the researchers includes study of frustrated magnetic systems, first-principle calculations using density functional theory, and modeling of the antibiotic selectivity and antibiotic resistance in a set of beta-lactamases.

Frustrated magnetic materials contain a wealth of interesting magnetic properties. Unlocking the mysteries of these magnets will not only deepen our understanding of the fundamental physics of these materials but may also provide clues for potential technological applications. Frustration can arise either due to the underlying geometry or due to competing interactions. In one work Dr. K. Majumdar and his collaborator Dr. G. Uhrig of Germany studied the dip in the energy dispersion at the boundary of the Brillouin zone in the isotropic Heisenberg quantum antiferromagnet. Their work has resulted in a peer-reviewed publication where they provided evidence that the description of the dip in terms of magnons can be improved significantly by applying more advanced evaluation schemes. In particular, they illustrated the usefulness of the application of the principle of minimal sensitivity in varied perturbation theory. Thereby, they provided an example for the application of this approach to an extended condensed matter problem governed by correlations which can trigger analogous investigations for many other systems. Recently Drs. Majumdar and S. Mahanti of Michigan State University has studied the Cr2(W,Te)O6 systems. They consist of bilayers with strong antiferromagnetic inter-bilayer coupling between Cr moments where the intra-bilayer coupling between the Cr moments can be tuned from ferro (for W) to antiferro (for Te). They calculated the energy dispersion and magnetization using a quantum Heisenberg spin Hamiltonian with tunable intra- and antiferromagnetic inter- bilayer couplings.  Their work has been submitted for publication.

Knowledge of the types of structural phase transformations and the conditions of their occurrence in intermetallic systems is fundamental for understanding their physical properties and their potential for functional applications. For example, some titanium-palladium-based alloys exhibit a shape-memory effect, a reversible phase transformation that can be induced and reversed either by applied stress or by change in temperature; due to their exceptional mechanical properties that can be manipulated as needed, these alloys are of interest for a variety of applications in medicine and engineering. Dr. M. Krcmar’s work utilized quantum-mechanical calculations based on the density-functional theory to study structural phase transformations in selected alloys, and explain under which conditions such transformations would occur. Her work shed some light on when and how the global lattice deformations couple with local atomic displacements in order to stabilize the final structures. The work also provided a model theory that can be used to predict structural phase transformation transition temperature in any system where its phase transformations can be effectively described by a single physical parameter. For Dr. Krcmar, the most significant outcomes resulting from the NSF award are publications of two journal articles, and mentoring of one undergraduate research project.
